Hi Nicolas, that was a good idea to try to organize some kind of classifi=
cation scheme and a great basis for discussion.  However, as you probably k=
now from talking to me I prefer not to call novelty "objective-driven" so I=
 wouldn't organize the table this way.  Of course, much of this discussion =
is just about words and semantics, so there may not be a definitive right a=
nd wrong, but I think drawing a distinction between objective-driven search=
es on the one hand and non-objective searches (including novelty) on the ot=
her is useful.

From my perspective, I think of an objective-driven search =
as one that is aiming at a particular area of the search space (which we wo=
uld call the "objective").  That cannot be said for novelty because it is n=
ot aiming anywhere in particular.  Your table does attempt to draw this dis=
tinction with the word "implicit" for novelty, but I think it's not even an=
 implicit objective because it's not aiming at anything in particular, impl=
icitly or explicitly.  

So in this way of thinking about it, I'd also say =
that artificial life domains generally are not objective either, because th=
ey are not aiming at any particular area of the search space.  And the same=
 can be said for natural evolution and Picbreeder as a whole.  While it is =
true in such systems that there is still selection, I would call the select=
ive pressure in those cases a "constraint" rather than an objective.  For e=
xample, novelty is a "constraint" on search, but as long as you are relativ=
ely novel, you will likely reproduce.  So you have a constraint without an =
objective.

The idea that some evolution is "biased" by some partial object=
ive pressure (like Avida) in my view would put it somewhere on the continuu=
m between objective and non-objective search.  So I think it's fair to thin=
k of it as a continuum between objective and non-objective with two extreme=
s. 

But whether or not it is environment-driven I think is a less importan=
t issue than whether it is objective or non-objective.  It's true that envi=
ronment-driven search tends to be more non-objective (like nature), but it'=
s possible that the environment is set up in such a way that it is like hav=
ing an objective.

But I think maybe more interesting than any of this is t=
hat when it comes to true open-ended innovation there are still other very =
important ingredients that none of these terms capture.  So for example bei=
ng non-objective may be necessary but not sufficient for a true open-ended =
complexity explosion.  That's one reason that many (or perhaps all) alife w=
ords so far fail to live up to nature.  So I think in reality as the critic=
al factors that enable open-ended evolution become better understood this c=
lassification scheme will expand to have new dimensions, regardless of whic=
h scheme we agree on at present.  Those new dimensions will likely also cha=
nge much of the basis for this type of discussion because they will split s=
ystems into different categories (along the new dimensions) that under pres=
ent schemes would be considered to be within the same category.

ken


I th=
ink the issue of whether it is "environment-driven" or

--- In neat@yahoogr=
oups.com, Nicolas Bredeche <nekonaute@...> wrote:
>
> Hi,
> 
> I understand=
 that this short discussion about target-based vs.
> non-target-based evolu=
tion may grow a bit off-topic, but I would love to
> take this discussion a=
 little further about the difference btw
> objective-driven and environment=
-driven evolution.
> 
> (...)
> 
> > > I'm also not sure whether it's reall=
y accurate to say Avida is "not
> > target-based." It's true that it's not =
as explicit as a single simple
> > objective function, but the fact that th=
ere are several logical operations
> > that explicitly give an advantage to=
 organisms that execute them actually
> > does create a form of objective-d=
riven pressure. In other words, the
> > creativity of evolution in Avida wi=
th such a priori human-defined rewards
> > is to some extent hampered by th=
e need to stay competitive on those
> > arbitrary objectives. So I'd expect=
 it to be closer to objective search
> > (when used in that mode) than non-=
objective search, though somewhere on the
> > continuum between them. I als=
o understand that Avida as a platform doesn't
> > have to be run with those=
 rewards, but if I understand correctly they are
> > traditional and used i=
n this particular paper as well.
> > >
> >
> > I agree with you. Avida is l=
ikely more towards non-objective search than
> > target-based search, but p=
robably not by that much. You'd likely get a
> > stronger argument from Cha=
rles Ofria about it being more open-ended, but
> > I've always thought that=
 Avida (and all alife simulations) are still rather
> > target-based. That'=
s why I don't put too much stock in the argument that
> > not having an exp=
licit fitness function makes some alife simulations more
> > interesting: I=
 usually think they do have an explicit fitness function,
> > it's just a c=
omplicated one that we don't understand as much as others.
> >
>  (...)
> 
=
> It seems to me that one additional property must be taken into account
> =
about how the selection pressure is actually applied. On the one hand,
> se=
lection can be implemented as an user-defined metric used to compare and
> =
rank individuals for selection/replacement, which is the classical way in
>=
 Evolutionary Robotics/Algorithms (incl. novelty search, ie. an explicit
> =
function formulating an implicit objective - though of course the search
> =
for novelty looks a lot like modelling the red queen). On the other hand,
>=
 selection can result from environmental pressure as it is the case with
> =
TIERRA (and to less extent, to AVIDA, IMHO), where selection/replacement
> =
does not depend on a performance value to be computed.
> 
> I agree with yo=
u both as AVIDA seems to stand inbetween as a performance
> measure is actu=
ally computed (the metabolic function) but is not directly
> used for selec=
tion/replacement. On the contraty, I always had the
> impression that TIERR=
A was something more on the side of "true" natural
> selection, environment=
-driven instead of target-based. Of course,
> minimizing program size in TI=
ERRA may be seen as the objective, but it is
> not explicitly formulated co=
mpared to AVIDA's metabolic functions which
> directly impact the duplicati=
on success (if i am not mistaken, as i am not
> an AVIDA practitionner).
> =

> In a recent paper co-authored with Jean-Marc Montanier (presented at the=

> EPS workshop at ALIFE 2012), we summarized some work on environment-driv=
en
> evolutionary adaptation of swarm of epucks robots done in the Symbrion=

> swarm/modular robotic project, and we faced the problem as to where our =
own
> work stands. We came up with some sort of (imperfect) classification =
as we
> tried to position our own work wrt. traditional Evolutionary Roboti=
cs (ER),
> Embodied Evolution (EE), ALIFE simulation about evolution (ALIFE=
). I just
> extracted an up-to-date image of the table from the paper so yo=
u may find
> it easily: check it
> here<http://www.lri.fr/%7Ebredeche/pub/t=
able-EPS2012.jpg>(EDEA is our
> own method, forget it if you wish, it is no=
t the point here).
> Of course, this is not meant as a definitive table as =
frontiers are
> somewhat blurred, as with the position of novelty search (w=
hich is also
> environment-driven in some way, but still explicitly formula=
ted) or AVIDA's
> metabolic function (which also makes AVIDA task-driven). =
I'd be curious if
> some of you have some feedback to provide on this globa=
l classification.
> 
> Cheers,
> 
> Nicolas
> 
> ps:  btw, i really enjoyed=
 reading your paper Jeff, inspiring and clearly
